docs.lead_paragraph: ''One thing you'll see is a lot of crowding,'' Stanley Crooke said. ''I don't want people too separated. That's not the way to make good drugs.'' He strode past immunology laboratories, an animal autopsy lab, several cold rooms, a chemical spill cabinet. ''One of my great decisions,'' he said, ''was to carpet the pedestrian hallways. It's cheaper and quieter.'' Mr. Crooke, the president of pharmaceutical research and development at the SmithKline Beckman Corporation, was showing off the mammoth research and development facility, still unfinished, that SmithKline is building on 300 acres in Upper Merion, on the outskirts of Philadelphia. The new complex is testimony to the riches showered on the company from a green pill that treats ulcers.
